Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant was denied procedural fairness and whether the officer erred in determining eligibility under IRPR
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) Subparagraph 76(1)(b)(i)
Basis_of_Claim: Failure to provide updated proof of funds after family size increased
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to submit required documentation by deadline
Application_Error: Officer’s decision issued one day prematurely
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for application assessment; Correctness for procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Change in family size affecting financial requirements
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in visa application process
Outcome: Application granted; officer's decision quashed and case remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable inferences based on conflicting statements and applicant's age
Basis_of_Claim: Rejection of sponsorship application due to alleged document fraud and inconsistencies
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide Khalid a meaningful opportunity to respond to concerns
Application_Error: Failure to inform Khalid of document concerns
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration by different officer
Document_Fraud: Alleged fraudulent documents submitted by applicant's sons

Application_Facts: Applicant provided a letter from employer and job duties description lacking details on responsibilities and remuneration.
Procedural_Issue: Allegation that visa officer breached procedural fairness by not requesting additional information.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed information on job responsibilities and remuneration
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer not obligated to seek clarification; applicant bears burden to provide sufficient evidence. Documents provided were insufficient.
Authority_Responsible: Visa officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration application decision
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to adequately clarify discrepancies in application
Evidence_Type: Net worth documentation, business experience records
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient evidence of net worth and business experience
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant had opportunities to respond but did not do so adequately
Decision_Maker: Visa officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Alleged insufficient supporting documentation and unaddressed discrepancies
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of factual conclusions and procedural fairness
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, reasonableness standard under administrative law
Application_Factor: Net worth, business experience, responsiveness to procedural inquiries
Decision_Outcome: Visa application rejected; judicial review dismissed
Document_Fraud: No explicit finding of document fraud, but credibility concerns related to application completeness

Application_Facts: The Minister did not provide evidence that the June 29, 2009 letter was sent to the applicant's representative; tribunal record and delivery notification were deemed insufficient.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to prove communication was sent to applicant's representative
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of affidavit evidence from the Minister confirming dispatch of communication
Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by the Minister with all materials considered
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal and reconsideration of application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Minister bears risk of failed communication without proof of transmission
Decision_Rationale: Absence of proper evidentiary proof (e.g., affidavit) that communication was sent renders the refusal invalid

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was breached by not considering applicant's response letter
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant claimed to have sent a response; burden on applicant to prove receipt
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Correspondence (response letter), communication records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation of employment details
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Burden on applicant to ensure delivery and receipt of response
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to confirm receipt of response letter
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness considering context, statutory scheme, and individual impact
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Alleged response letter not received or considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of modern communication methods allowing tracking
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found

Crimes.Crime_Name: Withholding material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was breached due to non-consideration of applicant’s response letter
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant claimed timely submission; no proof of receipt provided
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Response letter, communication records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding or misrepresenting employment experience
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's responsibility to ensure delivery and confirm receipt
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to follow up on submission of response
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Alleged response not received by visa officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Availability of tracked communication methods

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer breached the duty of fairness in communication methods
Evidence_Assessment: Email address provided on Use of a Representative form; initial email received without objection; follow-up request sent to correct email address
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Credibility_Factor: Applicant and counsel failed to respond or clarify communication preferences
Legal_Rule: If an email address is provided and not revoked, it is valid for official communication
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of duty of fairness in using email for communication
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of a Representative form with email address
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, procedural fairness in immigration decisions
Defendant_Response: No objection raised by counsel regarding email communication
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), procedural fairness principles

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness due to non-receipt of request for additional documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of non-receipt not accepted
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Proof of mailing with correct address
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Proof that letter was sent to correct address
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to submit complete passport copies
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior opportunities to submit documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness due to non-receipt of reminder letter
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of non-receipt not credible given proof of mailing
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Proof of mailing to correct address, no return of mail
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to receive critical communication
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of non-delivery shifts to applicant when proof of sending exists
Crimes.Application_Error: Incomplete submission of required documents
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior reminders and opportunities to comply
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Failure to disclose previous refusals or provide full documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequate consideration of factors in H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence for abuse, credible risk, or hardship
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence exceeding normal expectations
Crimes.Application_Error: None found
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard under IRPA

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Pannu overstayed her visa and applied for H&C relief
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Treatment as divorced woman in India
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Factors considered but not sufficient to meet threshold
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal error; decision within acceptable range

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of officer’s consideration in H&C refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged ignored evidence not substantiated
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence supporting exemption
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness under IRPA

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with deportation order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Third H&C application following deportation order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Hardship not shown to be unusual or disproportionate
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from removal on H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision rational and within bounds of reasonableness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer’s consideration of H&C factors after work permit expiry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed but not sufficient for relief
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exceptional hardship if removed
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence meeting H&C threshold
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged disregard of key factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard under IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in failing to analyze whether the applicant's experience constituted a well-founded fear of persecution or compelling reasons for refugee protection
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, s. 96 (Convention refugees), s. 97 (persons in need of protection), s. 108(4) (exceptions for compelling reasons)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found inconsistencies and lack of evidence affecting credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Generalized violence in Haiti following reporting of sexual assault
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of personalized risk and nexus to Convention grounds
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to assess compelling reasons under s. 108(4)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; compelling reasons for protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Past sexual assault and reporting it
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Victim_Status: Female individual claiming persecution based on gender-based violence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Trauma from past sexual assault, vulnerability as a woman reporting crime
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk rather than targeted threat
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Claimed but not established by Board
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical or police reports (if any)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially accepted (assault acknowledged, but future risk not substantiated)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible about past assault, but insufficient link to ongoing persecution

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection based on state inability to protect
Crimes.Outcome: Claim denied due to lack of personalized risk
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of harm due to past sexual assault and lack of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic implementation under IRPA
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.Protected_Group: Women in Haiti subjected to gender-based violence
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State unable or unwilling to provide protection against non-state actors
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Membership in particular social group (women fearing gender-based violence)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization involved in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLM, which was linked to an attack in Namibia; evidence reasonably supports CLM's involvement in subversion.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No direct misrepresentation found, but inconsistencies in statements raised concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review conducted based on reasonableness and correctness standards
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of CLM membership, links between CLM and the 1999 attack in Namibia, leadership connection to Mr. Muyongo
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Some inconsistencies in applicant's statements, but not sufficient to undermine decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially credible with noted inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere membership in an organization engaged in subversion by force is sufficient for inadmissibility under s. 34(1)(f)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged error in finding inadmissibility despite lack of direct involvement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether ID erred in finding Tjiueza inadmissible under s. 34(1)(f) due to inconsistencies and denial of violent involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns due to discrepancies in statements about CLM/CLA identity and activities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, documentary links between CLM and 1999 attack
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Membership in organization deemed to engage in subversion by force
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Admission of CLM membership and conflation of CLM with CLA responsible for attack
Crimes.Application_Error: None found – ID’s interpretation upheld
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of factual findings and legal interpretation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of application for relief under s. 34(2)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force of a government
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization involved in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLM; ID found reasonable grounds to link CLM to 1999 attack under Mr. Muyongo’s leadership
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in statements led to credibility concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessing factual and legal basis of ID decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Membership admission, organizational links to violent attack, leadership structure
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inconsistencies, but overall evidence deemed sufficient
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially credible – discrepancies noted but did not invalidate conclusion
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere membership suffices for inadmissibility if organization engaged in subversion by force

Legal_Issue: Whether the risk faced by applicants was generalized or specific
Evidence_Type: Testimony, incident of mistaken identity killing, gang threats
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by Mara 13 gang in El Salvador
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Specific targeting by gang after reporting theft to police
Evidence_Ignored: Specific threats and incidents following police report
Legal_Standard: Different in degree from general population risk
Application_Factor: Mistaken identity killing, direct gang threats
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer breached principles of fairness by not updating the application after a two-year delay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 113(a)
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred; PRRA decision stands
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged new risk was deemed implausible given prior RPD findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of new or updated evidence from applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claim of increased personal risk upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to provide updated information during the delay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to update application with new circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — no new evidence was submitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers must assess new evidence but are not required to solicit updates
Crimes.Application_Factor: Two-year processing delay, applicant inaction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of new evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 113(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar remained in Canada after her visa expired while pursuing protection claims
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable — violation based on status, not false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PRRA decision and removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, lack of updated submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide new evidence supporting continued stay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Increased risk claim unsubstantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on PRRA application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for PRRA, correctness for jurisdictional issues
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural unfairness; applicant had opportunity to update but did not

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar failed to depart Canada after final removal order was issued
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged oral deferral request not documented or acknowledged
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of removal process
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal interview records, absence of written deferral request
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of formal deferral request
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of oral deferral request not accepted
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order remains valid and enforceable
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Set aside removal order or defer removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No duty to defer without clear request or practical impediment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Suspected fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was violated in assessing credibility of relationship
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision upheld; no procedural breach found
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Relationship claims lacked corroboration and consistency
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of updated documentation or communication records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return due to changed personal circumstances
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide new evidence supporting genuine relationship
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not disclose or substantiate marital status changes
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers assess risk based on submitted evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of denied refugee claim and lack of cooperation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicion of sham marriage not proven but contributed to credibility concerns

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in PRRA and removal processes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA and removal officers respected natural justice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on existing record; no duty to seek new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent claims and lack of follow-up
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers must act fairly but are not required to prompt applicants for updates
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Two-year delay, alleged oral deferral request
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of updated submissions or formal deferral request
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CBSA and IRCC maintained decisions were procedurally fair
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written PRRA application, removal interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a), IRPA; common law procedural fairness

Legal_Issue: Violation of natural justice principles
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review, set aside decision, remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Assumption made about applicant's intent to return without opportunity to respond
Evidence_Type: Applicant's ties to Colombia, study history in Canada
Basis_of_Claim: Assumed lack of intent to leave Canada after studies
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of opportunity to address concerns about intent to return
Application_Error: Failure to provide applicant chance to clarify intent
Evidence_Ignored: Potential evidence of ties to Colombia
Legal_Standard: Natural justice, fairness in administrative decision-making
Application_Factor: Duration of study in Canada affecting perceived ties to home country
Decision_Outcome: Denial of study permit and temporary resident visa

Legal_Issue: Did the Board misinterpret s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act and fail to apply it properly?
Outcome: The application is allowed, and the matter is returned for redetermination by a new panel due to the Board's legal error.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Jiminez claimed refugee status based on past persecution in El Salvador, but the Board rejected his claim.
Application_Error: Focused on current psychological state post-brain injury rather than nature of past persecution
Evidence_Ignored: Severity and appalling nature of past torture in El Salvador
Legal_Standard: Whether the Board correctly applied s. 2(3)
Application_Factor: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Board failed to consider severity of past persecution
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a newly constituted panel
Evidence_Source: Testimony of Mr. Jiminez regarding torture
Basis_for_Decision: Severe torture suffered in the past
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to assess compelling reasons under s. 2(3)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer followed proper procedure and applied guidelines fairly
Crimes.Governing_Law: De Facto Illegal Residents Program guidelines
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged misrepresentations were not properly assessed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, cross-examinations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Guidelines under the De Facto Illegal Residents Program
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to follow fair and humane assessment procedures
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of opportunity for applicant to respond
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider overall circumstances including economic and social establishment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and natural justice
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of stay since 1981, social integration
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter or correctness depending on issue

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Governing_Law: De Facto Illegal Residents Program guidelines
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa since 1981, applied under regularization program
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged but not substantiated with proper process
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No opportunity given to respond to allegations
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration manager to reject recommendation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documented reasoning for refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not adequately conducted
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of application and halt to deportation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to follow program guidelines and ensure fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit and residency refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Fairness and adherence to immigration guidelines in refusal decision
Crimes.Governing_Law: De Facto Illegal Residents Program guidelines
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged misrepresentations not verified through fair process
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, cross-examinations, officer recommendation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Improper rejection despite initial approval recommendation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of procedural fairness and failure to assess economic establishment
Crimes.Application_Error: Rejection without allowing response or full assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compliance with program guidelines and natural justice
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long-term presence and social ties in Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of application leading to legal challenge
Crimes.Authority: Department of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged false statements in application materials

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements to Immigration Officials
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant changed story from extortion to religious persecution after arrival, provided no corroborative evidence, claimed fear of return to Fujian Province.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Changed reason for fleeing from extortion to religious persecution without supporting evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Fujian Province
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No corroborative evidence for religious persecution claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's credibility lacking due to inconsistencies and lack of evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, no question for certification
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credibility undermined by inconsistent narrative and lack of evidence; country conditions in Fujian not supportive of widespread religious persecution

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and sur place claim assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD erred in assessing credibility and sur place claim
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies between initial claim of extortion and later claim of religious persecution
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Religious persecution in China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false passport and change in narrative
Crimes.Application_Error: Initial false statement regarding reason for fleeing
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution due to protected grounds
Crimes.Application_Factor: Post-arrival change in basis of claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD’s denial of refugee status upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fabricated passport to enter Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility of religious persecution claim and RPD assessment of country conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD reasonably assessed applicant's claim and country conditions in Fujian
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD considered lack of corroborative evidence and conflicting country reports
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD’s decision to deny refugee status upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Change in narrative from extortion to religious persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Convention refugee must face serious risk due to race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution in Fujian Province, China
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to contradictions and omissions in testimony and forms
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, written statements, Personal Information Forms (PIFs)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and refugee eligibility under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to threats in home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and failure to test state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of key information in application forms and inconsistencies in statements
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; Board considered all relevant evidence consistent with its mandate
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for negative credibility findings and burden to demonstrate lack of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in accounts of persecution and failure to seek local protection
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No forgery, but material omissions and misrepresentations in official forms

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to an immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on applicant's credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to contradictions between entry statements and testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Port of entry statements, hearing testimony, application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions prohibiting false statements in immigration proceedings
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by PRI members in Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent identification of persecutors and lack of proof regarding state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Contradictions at port of entry and omission of critical details
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found Board’s analysis sufficient and evidence properly weighed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for assessing credibility and rebutting presumption of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: False or inconsistent statements about identity of persecutors
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False oral/written statements at entry, not document forgery

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts in Personal Information Form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on lack of credibility and failure to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by contradictions and omissions in PIF and testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form (PIF), oral testimony, supporting documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Requirements for full disclosure in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Threats from Mexican political party members
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Material omissions in PIF and failure to access state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose knowledge of fraud and inconsistencies in political timeline
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication of ignored evidence; Board relied on available credible information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to disclose material facts and burden to prove ineffective state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Non-disclosure of key facts in mandatory forms
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed, no relief granted on judicial review
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Material omissions in official immigration form (PIF)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the marriage genuine or primarily for acquiring Canadian status?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) Regulations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony affected credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage not genuine, entered for immigration benefits
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Hasty marriage and prior immigration attempts
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Marriage must be genuine and not primarily for status acquisition
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of behavior suggesting immigration motive

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the marriage genuine or primarily for acquiring Canadian status?
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal dismissed due to marriage fraud allegations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in statements affected credibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulations invalidating marriages primarily for status acquisition
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage motivated by immigration benefits
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Hasty marriage and prior visa attempts
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Marriage must be genuine and not primarily for status
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of immigration-related applications

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Prior criminal record for sexual offenses
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk due to criminal history
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and relied upon by panel
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment due to criminal history and hasty relationship

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the tribunal's decision on refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's evasive testimony, delayed departure, returns to Haiti
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, travel history, asylum history in the U.S.
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA (refugee definition)
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by an armed gang in Haiti
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of the applicant and plausibility of subjective fear
Application_Error: Inconsistent behavior and lack of timely asylum seeking

Violation_Type: Failure to apply correct legal test for state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Presumption of state protection under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and burden of proof
Application_Facts: Hungarian Roma family claimed refugee status due to systemic discrimination and lack of effective state protection in Hungary
Claimant_Status: Roma family from Hungary seeking refugee protection
Procedural_Issue: Inconsistent application of legal standard; Board initially stated correct standard but applied a lower threshold ('somewhat rebut')
Evidence_Used: Evidence of discrimination against Roma community in Hungary, claims of inadequate state response
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to meet clear and convincing evidence standard to rebut presumption of state protection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status initially granted by Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Minister sought judicial review of RPD's grant of refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of the case for reconsideration by a different member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities with requirement to provide clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption of state protection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, correctness for questions of law
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to consistently apply the correct legal test, creating uncertainty in the decision-making process
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent demonstrated 'special circumstances' excusing nonuse of the trademark 'PROMODE' under s. 45 of the Trade Marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 56 of the Trade Marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Delays due to organizational challenges, industry cycles, key personnel resignations, and deliberate business planning were assessed as valid
Burden_of_Proof: Respondent bore the burden to show special circumstances for nonuse
Credibility_Factor: Senior Hearing Officer found respondent's evidence credible and sufficient
Legal_Rule: Under s. 45, nonuse of a trademark may lead to expungement unless excused by special circumstances
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Registrar's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Appellants claimed nonuse of 'PROMODE' without justification
Key_Evidence_Considered: Organizational delays, industry cycles, resignation of key personnel, strategic business planning
Defendant_Response: Respondent argued special circumstances justified nonuse
Evidence_Type: Documentary and factual evidence of business operations and challenges
Outcome: Appeal dismissed with costs; registration upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 45 and s. 56 of the Trade Marks Act
Authority: Senior Hearing Officer, Registrar of Trademarks

Legal_Issue: Entitlement to mandamus; Charter rights violation
Evidence_Assessment: Delays due to policy changes; no binding representations
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show unreasonable delay and entitlement to relief
Credibility_Factor: No evidence of bad faith or arbitrary conduct by Minister
Legal_Rule: Mandamus requires unreasonable delay, no justification, and equity; Charter s.7 and s.15 not applicable to non-citizens outside Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable delay; alleged violation of Charter rights and rule of law
Outcome_on_Merits: No entitlement to mandamus or Charter relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Changes in processing priorities and quotas
Legal_Framework: IRPA discretion; principles of administrative law; Charter applicability
Defendant_Response: Delays due to legitimate policy adjustments; no Charter obligations
Remedy_Requested: Order of mandamus; declaration of Charter violation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Brown served 17 months pre-trial; Crown suggested 2:1 credit; sentencing judge imposed 1 additional day in jail
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or Protected Person (implied by deportation context)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether pre-sentence incarceration counts toward the 'term of imprisonment'
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD's jurisdiction to hear appeal based on length of sentence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear judicial intent to grant 2:1 credit for pre-trial custody
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in assuming automatic 2:1 credit
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order based on serious criminality
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pre-trial custody may count if considered part of punishment, but no automatic doubling without judicial intent

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Robbery with potential use of weapon (contextual link)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of imitation firearm (linked to co-charge)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Credit for pre-trial custody considered but not clearly applied
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (indictable offence with potential for lengthy sentence)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to violent nature and firearm involvement
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential for reoffending or threat to community
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for conviction but ambiguity in sentencing details
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Judicial record, sentencing transcript
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but incomplete regarding credit application
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Inclusion and calculation of pre-trial custody toward two-year threshold under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using an imitation firearm during the commission of an offence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of imitation firearm increasing danger and severity

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to weapon involvement
